Why don't you invite an independent review of the page then? https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1994/11/14/o-guru-guru-guru and https://www.salon.com/2010/08/14/eat_pray_love_guru_sex_scandals Anyone who isn't a Siddha person will emphasize these legitimate mainstream sources over dusty old web pages on Siddha's own web site. Someone please protect this page from propaganda!!!

TheRingess is very obviously working on behalf of the Siddha Yoga organization to ensure this page includes nothing but their gauzy propaganda. Google Gurumayi's write-ups in Salon and the New Yorker if you want the story of who this human woman was, and not all this cult-y pablum that TheRingess tirelessly enforces on this decidedly non-neutral, hagiographic page.

Hate Gurumayi? Nah, she's a fox. I hate that SYDA won't come clean that she has been MIA for almost 20 years. I can't tell if you are actually in denial that she is long gone, or just working to maintain the Siddha facade. Ah, well. Sorry the truth is too much for you.

There is no plausible rationale for excluding the Lis Harris reference. It is a major media profile of Gurumayi.

You are asserting that she is appearing live, then citing a highly biased source from Siddha Yoga which offers no photographic or video evidence, only claims that inherently serve the organization's interest. For now, her appearance over live-streaming is merely an unsubstantiated and unverified claim made by an organization that stands to profit from making that claim. Please cite actual neutral evidence or else just leave this out?

Disagree. Change it when it re-opens. If it ever does.
Restoring essential Harris and Shah reporting.
/* Use of a reference 12 years old to say that Chidvilasananda has disappeared */ Reply

Please leave the Salon.com reporting about her last verified public appearance in place until you can site a credible third-party source proving a more recent public appearance. Your statements as a Siddha devotee, unsupported by evidence, are not appropriate for an encyclopedia entry.

Her last verified public appearance was in 2004, as reported in Salon.com. The Siddha organization and Siddha devotees assert that she is still teaching, but that is just gossip without a credible third-party source to contradict Salon.com's claim.
Added important detail about last public appearance.
Removed PRASAD de Mexico source as it does not confirm 26,087 claim
Added note about ashram no longer accepting visitors
Fixed the embedded quote marks in shaktipat quote
Guru doesn't make sense as a header. Fixed.
Removed reference to SYDA publication and promotion. This is an encyclopedia, not a promotional brochure for Siddha Yoga.
Removed ambiguous information about Nityananda better suited to his page
Removed New York Times Article about celebrity devotees -- if Lis Harris's article isn't worth including, then this one certainly is not.
Removed various promotional materials from Siddha Yoga organization

Removed claim about 2020 live stream and preposterous link to Siddha yoga site which offers wild claims with nothing remotely resembling evidence. Please cite a credible, neutral source to substantiate this claim, or else stop asserting it. This amounts to marketing from Siddha Yoga. It is not a suitable source.
Edited reference section for more consistency and neutrality
No evidence to support recent Siddha organizations' claim of recent livestreaming activity.

Disagree. You are whitewashing the Harris source. Baba's page has a controversy section. Harris's and Shah's reporting show up high in Google results. Your quest to suppress this information is futile.

You can't make Harris's article sound like nothing, just because you want to present Gurumayi in an ideal light. Also removed Shaktipat section -- a reference to her written work will suffice -- this page is not meant to advertise her writing.
There is no plausible case for omitting Lis Harris's profile -- the only major media profile of Gurumayi ever to be completed. Harris's source must be included and accurately summarized.
The New Yorker and Salon.com articles belong on this page. If you can find another way to include them that honestly represents their content, then feel free.
Extensive major media reporting has focused specifically on Baba's serial abuse of young girls. "Controversy" is too vague and whitewashing.
You're right -- personal accounts from Siddha members such as yourself are not appropriate. Shah's reporting is a source. And don't call it a tabloid -- it is not.
/* Muktananda */ Reply
Adding back credible academic and media articles that Siddha followers keep deleting.

This page cannot contain unsubstantiated claimed made by the Siddha Yoga organization. Anyone affiliated with Siddha is too biased to edit this page in anything but a progagandistic way. Please cite major media sources, not the Siddha site.

BLP policies only apply to living figures. If you have evidence that Gurumayi is still living and still active in Siddha, please provide a credible source that confirms that she is still alive -- not just a long written article on the Siddha Yoga web site asserting that without providing any credible evidence.
/* Muktananda */ Reply

"Neutral" does not mean solely positive and propagandistic. The page needs to include the credibly, widely reported allegations of her disappearance, her abusive behavior, and her enabling of others' abusive behavior. If you can find a way to word that important aspect of her biography more "neutrally," then please revise. If you keep simply removing it, I will keep adding it back.
Siddha Yoga members, please stop editing this page to conceal credibly reported and cited evidence of sexual exploitation?

Deleting credible, balanced reporting does not serve the page's neutrality. Siddha Yoga members are consistently editing this page to make it propagandistic and idealistic. Please stop deleting credibly reported content that yields a more balanced picture of Gurumayi.
